title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: From this point it continues northwards by Markinch to Falkland (24: miles).

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: " Weel, weel," she continued, " I'm glad ye cam', for I'd ne'er believed but that they were a' black, had I na' seen ye;" and with a smile at her simple innocence I bade her goodby,  and returned to Markinch, past the ruins of Arnot Castle, and through the beautiful valley of the Biver Lcven, and arrived at the Scottish capital, after a pleasant day's excursion to the birth and burial-place of Michael Bruce.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: I left Edinburgh in the morning and proceeded to Granton Pier, from which place I crossed the Frith of Forth, and took rail to Markinch, the nearest station to Portmoak, the burial-place of Bruce.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
